XXXIV 25 430
While among the villages
of the CKasabiKasabi we saw
no evidence of want of
food ^ among the people - Our
beads were very valuable
but cotton cloth would
have been still more so
for as we travelled along
men and women and children
and came running after
us with ^ meal & fowls for sale
which we would gladly
have purchased had we
possessed any of our
English manufactures
When they heard that we
had no cloth they turned
back much disappointed

The amount of
population in the central
parts of the country may
be called large only as
compared with the
Cape Colony or Griqua
the Bechuana country and
tThe cultivated land is
as nothing when compared
with what might be
brought under the plough
There are flowing streams
in abundance towhich
were it necessary could
be turned out with but
little labour for the purpose
of irrigation - Miles of
431
fruitful country are now laying
absolutely waste for there is not even
game to eat off the fine pasturage
and recline under the ever-
-green shady groves which
26 we are ever passing
in our progress - The people
who inhabit the central region
are not all ^ quite black ^ in colour - Many incline
to that colour of bronze and
others are as light coloured
in hue ^ as the Bushmen - who it may
be remembered afford a proof
that heat alone does not
cause ˄ deep blackness, andbut also that
heat and moisture combined
do mvery materially deepen
the colour - Wherever we
find people who have continued
for ages in a hot humid
district they are deep black
but to this apparent law
there are exceptions caused
by the migrations of both
tribes and individuals
The Makololo for instance
among the tribes of the
humid central basin appear
of a sickly sallow hue
and when compared with
the aboriginal inhabitants
The Batoka also who
lived onin an elevated
region are when seen
432
in company with the Batoka
of the rivers so much
lighter in colour they
might be taken for another
27 tribe but their language
and very marked custom
of knocking out the upper
front teeth leave not
room for doubt that they
are one people -

Apart from the influences
of elevation - heat & humidity
and degradation I have been led to remark
that the deeper hue was
evidence of degradation
imagined that I remarkedobserved
the lighter and darker
colours running in five
Longitudinal bands along the
Southern portion of the continent - The
sea board on both the
East and West very dark
Then two bands beginning
about three hundred miles
from each coast That
on the West bending
round and embracing
the Kalahari desert and
Bechuana countries - Here
the people are all of
a lighter hue and then
the central basin very
dark again - This view
433
is not given with any degree
of positiveness - It is stated
just as it struck my mind
in passing accross the
country and if incorrect
it is singular that the
28 dialects spoken by the
different tribes have
arranged themselves in a
somewhat similar fashion
which weseems to indicate
migration along the lines
of colour - If you compare
the dialects If the dialects
spoken in the extreme
Thorns
255 South [whether Hottentot
or KCaffre they will be
found to bear ^ bear a close
affinity to those of
the tribes ^ living immediately
on their Northern borders
one glides into the other
and their affinities are so
easily detected that they
are at once recognizedrecognised
to be cognate - But if
the dialects of extreme
points are compared
as that of the Caffres
and the tribes near the
Equator it is more
difficult to recognizerecognise
the fact that they
which is really the case
434
that all the dialects belong
to but two families of
languages - But examination
of the roots of the words
of the dialects arranged
in geographical order
poses shewsshows that they
29 glide in meltmerge into each
other

Chester 4th March Having reached the village
of Njambi one of the chiefs
of the Chiboque or as the
Portuguese wen intended
to pass a quiet Sunday
and our provisions
being quite spent I ordered
a kid & tired riding ox to be slaughtered
The Chiboque and other
tribes in this direction
disfigure themselves
by filing or chipping
their teeth to a point
As we wished to be on
good terms with all we
sent the hump and
ribs to Njambi with
the explanation that this
was the customary
tribute to chiefs in the
part from which we
had come and that we
always honoured men
in this position - We
435
He returned thanks and promised
to send food next morning
Next morning however he
sent an impudent message with a very
small present
of meal he
instead and scorning the
meat he had accepted and
demanding ˄ either a man an ox - a
gun powder cloth or a shell -
30 and in the event of refusal
and in the event of refusal
to ^ heto intcomply with his demand
he intimated his intention
to prevent our further progress
We replied we should have
thought ourselves fools if we
we had scorned his small
present and demanded
other food - And supposing
we had possessed the
articles named no black
man ought to impose a
tribute on a party that
did not trade in slaves
The servants who brought
the message said that
when sent to the Mambari
they had always got a
quantity of cloth from
them for their master
and now expected the
same or something else
as an equivalent ^ from me - All the
women who had brought
meal to purchase meat
from my men

436
We heard some of the
Chiboque remark "they have
only five guns" and about
midday oNjambiNjambi collected
all his people and
surrounded our encampment
encampment - Their object
31 was evidently to plunder
us of everything - My men
seized their javelins &
stood on the defensive
while the young Chiboque
had drawn their swords
and brandished them with
great fury - Some even
pointed their guns at me
and nodded to each
other as much to say
"this is the way we shall
do with him" - I myput my double
barrelled gun I sat down
on my camp stool
with my double barrelled
gun accross my knees
and invited the chief
to be seated also - When
he and his counsellors
sat down on the ground
in front of me I asked
what guilt we had incurred
that he had come armed
in that way - He replied
that one of my Makololo
men) (Pitsane) while sitting at the
fire that morning, had
437
in spitting allowed a small
quantity of the saliva to
fall on the leg on one
of his men, and this "guilt"
he wanted to be settled by a
fine of a man, ox, or guns -
Pitsane admitted the fact
32 of a little saliva having
fallen accidentally on
the Chiboque that and in
proof its being ^ a pure accident
mentioned that he had
just given the man a
piece of meat by way
of making friends just
before it happened
and wiped it off with
his hand as soon as it
fell - In reference to a
man being given I declared
that we were all ready
to die rather than give
up one of our number
to be a slave - that theymy
men might as well give
me as I give one of
them - for we were all
free men - Then you can
give the gun with which
the ox was shot - As we
heard some of hhis people
remarking even now that
we had only "five guns"
we declined that as then
on the ground that as they
were intent on plundering us
438
giving a gun would be helping do so them to do so This they denied
saying they
wanted the
customary
tribute only
I asked what
right they had
to ask payment
for leave to
tread on the
ground of God
our common
Father: if we
trod on their
gardens we
would pay
but not for
marching
on land which
was still God's
& not theirs
They did not
attempt to
controvert this
because it is
in accordance
with their own
ideas but
reverted again
to the pretended
crime of the
saliva
33 they could plunder us of
everything - My men now
entreated me to give something
and after asking the chief if
he really thought the affair
of the spitting a matter of
"guilt" and had recievedreceived an
answer in the affirmative
I gave him one of my
shirts - The young Chiboque
were dissatisfied and
began shouting and branddishing
their swords for more
a greater fine As Pitsane entreated felt
that he had been the
cause of this disagreeable
affair he asked me
to add something else -
I gave a bunch of beads
but the counsellors were
objected this time - so I added
a large hankdkerchief - The
more I yielded the more
unreasonable their demands
became - and at every
fresh - demand a shout
was made by the armed
party and a rush made
around us with brandishing
of arms - One young
man made a charge
at my head from
behind but I brought
round the muzzle of
my gun to his mouth
439
and he retreated - I pointed him
out to the chief and he ordered
34 him to retire a little - I felt
anxious to avoid the effusion
of blood and though sure of
being able with my Makololo
who had been drilled by
Sebituane to drive off twice
the number of our assailants
though now a large body
and well armed with both
spears swords, arrows
and guns - I strove to avoid
actual collision - My men
were quite unprepared
for this exhibition but
behaved with admirable
coolness - The chief and
counsellors by accepting
my invitation to be seated
had placed themselves
in a trap for my men
very quietly surrounded
them and appeared as if
made them feel that
there was no chance of
their escaping their spears
of my men I then said
that as one thing after
another had failed to
satisfy them it was
evident they wanted to
fight while we wanted
to pass peaceably through
440
the country - that they must
begin first and bear the
guilt before
God We would not
fight till they had struck
the first blow - then sat
35 silent for some time - It was
rather trying for me because
I knew that the Chiboque
would aim first at the
White man - ˄ first but I was careful
not to appear flurried and
having four barrels ready
for instant action looked
quietly at the savage scene
around - The Chiboque
countenance by no means
handsome is not improved
by the practice of filing
the teeth to a point which
they have adopted - The
chief and counsellors seingseeing
that they were in more
danger than I did not
choose our decision that
they should begin first strike
begin the strifeby striking the first blow and then see
what we could do and perhaps influenced
by seeing some
of my men
appearing
quite at home
in prospect of
a work of
blood -

The Chiboque at last put
the matter before us in this
way - "You come among us
in a new way - and say
you are quite friendly
how can we know it
unless you gave us some
of your food and you
take some of ours - If
441
you give us an ox we shall
give you whatever you may
wish and then we shall
be friends - In accordance
with the entreaties of my
men I gave an ox - and when
36 asked what I should like in
return mentioned food as that
which we most needed
In the evening Njambi sent
a very small presentbasket of meal
and a ftwo or three pounds
of the flesh of our own ox!
with the apology that he
had no fowls and very
little of any other food -
It was impossible to avoid
a laugh at the coolness of
the generous creatures, and
thankful that though resolved
to die rather than deliver
up one of our number
to be a slave we had so
far gained our point as
to be allowed to pass
on without having shed
human blood -

Dennett In the midst of the
commotion several Chiboque
stole pieces of meat out
of the sheds of my people,
and but one of the Makololo
went boldly into the crowd
and took back a marrow
bone from one of them
442
A few of my Batoka seemed
afraid, and would perhaps
have fled, had the fray
actually begun, but upon
the whole I thought my men
behaved admirably, and
they excited my admiration;
37 They lamented having left
their shields at home
by command of Sekeletu,
who He feared that if they
had carried these they
might would be more disposed
to be overbearing in their
demeanordemeanour to the tribes we
should meet - We had
proceeded on the principles
of peace and conciliation
and the foregoing treatment
in what they shewsshows
in what light our conduct
was viewed - In fact
we were taken for
interlopers trying to cheat
the revenue of the tribe
They had been accustomed
to get a slave or two from
every slave trader who passed
them, and now that we
disputed the right they viewed
the infringement on what
they considered lawfully due
with most virtuous
indignation

443
6th March As we were informed
that the people on the West
of the Chiboque of Njambi
were familiar with the
visits of slave traders, and
that it was the opinion
38 of our guides from Kangenke
that they so many
of my companions would
be demanded from me
in the same manner
the people of Njambi had
done, that I ^ wshould reach
the coast without a single
attendant, I resolved to
alter our course and
strike away to the N- N- E-North North East,
in the hope that at some
point farther North I
might should find an exit to
the Portuguese settlement
of Cassange - We then pro-
-ceeded at first due North,
with the Kasabi ^ villages on our
right and the KasauKasai on
our left - During the first
twenty miles we crossed
many small but now
swollen streams, having
the usual boggy banks
and whenever the
water stood for any
length of time it was
discoloured with rust of
-iron - We saw a Nakong
444
one day, a rare sight in this
quarter, and many new
and pretty flowers adorned
the vallieseys - We could observe
the difference in the seasons
in our Northing in company
39 with the sun - Summer
was now nearly over
at Kuruman - and far
advanced at Linyanti,
but here we were in the
middle of it - Fruits, which
we had eaten ripe on
the Leeambye, were here
quite green, - But we had
were ^ now comengcoming into the region
where the inhabitants are
favoured with two crops
and rainy seasons and
two crops i-e-id est when the sun is
going South and when
he comes back in
his way to the North, as
he was doing now

On the 8th one of the
men had left an ounce
or two of powder at our
sleeping place, and went
back for it several miles
for it - My clothing
being wet from crossing
a stream I was compeledcompelled
to wait for him - Had
I been moving in the
sun - I should have felt no harm
445
but the inaction led to a
violent fit of fever; The
continuance of this attack
was a source of much
Goodby regret, for we went [on
40 next day to a small
rivulet called Chihuné
in a lovely valley, and
had for a wonder
a clear sky - and a clear
moon - but such was
the confusion produced
in the mind by the
state of the body that
th I could scarcely manage
after some hourshours' trial
to get a Lunar observation
in which I could repose
confidence - The Chihune
Chihuné flows into the Longe
and that into the
Chihombo a feeder of
the Kasai - Those who
know the difficulties
of taking ^ altitudes and times and
distances and committing
all of them to paper will
sympathize with me
in this and many
other similar instances
446
While at Chihune the men inof
a village brought wax for
sale and on finding that
we wished for honey went
off and soon brought a
hive for sale - All the
41 bees in the country are
in possession of the
natives for they place
hives sufficient for them
all and When we knew
this we never attended the
call of the honey guide
for we were sure it
would only lead us to so to a
hive we had no right
to touch - The bird continues
its dutiesy habit of cainviting attention
of the honey though now
never actually needed
My Makololo lament that
they never knew before
that wax could be sold
for anything of value
and make resolutions as
as to their future # The forests
being more dense as we
proceed beyond Chihune
our guides wandered away
to the Westward again

Goodby As we have a
succession of open lawns
and deep forests it is
interesting to observe
447
something like instinct developed
even in trees - One which
when cut emits a milky juice
if when met with on the
open lawns grows as
42 an ordinary umbrageous
tree - and shewsshows [no
252 disposition to be a climber -
But when planted in a
forest it takes the same
form then sends out
a climbing branch
which twines round
another tree untill it
rises to the thirty or forty
feet or to the level of
the other trees of the
and these spread out
another crown again where it can
enjoy a fair share
of the sun - - In
parts ^ of the forest more dense still
than this, it assumes
the form of a climber
entirely ^ and at once takes
the assistance
of a tall neighbour
by winding
vigorously
round it without attempting
to form a lower head - -
It does not succeed
so well as native
born parasites but
but where not forced
to contend for space
with them it may be
mistaken for one which
is always a climber
448
The paths here were very narrow
and very much encumbered
with gigantic climbers
There must be some reason
why they prefer to go up
43 in a tree in the common
form of the thread of a
screw more than in
the other - On the one bank
of the Chihune they wound
up from left to right
inon the other rigfrom right
to left - I imagined this
was owing to the sun
being inat one season
of the year on their
North and inat another
on their south But on
the Leeambye I observed
creepers winding up
on opposite sides of the
same reed and makeing
a figure like the lacings
of a sandal

In passing through
these narrow paths I had
had an opportunity of
observing the peculiarities
of my ox "Sinbad" He
had a softer back than
the others but a much
more intractable temper
His horns were bent down-
wards ^ and hung
loosely so he could do no
449
harm with them but as we
woun wended our way
slowly along the narrow
path he would suddenly
44 dart aside - A string tied to a stick put through
the cartilage of the nose
isserves instead of a bridle
If you jerk this back
it makes him run faster
on: Iif you pull it to one
side he allows the nose
and head to go but keeps
the opposite eye open
and directed to the forbidden
spot and goes in spite
of you - The only way
he can be brought to
a stand is by a stroke
with a wand across
the nose - When he can
ran Sinbad ran in
below a climber stretched
over the path and so
low I could not duck
under it I was dragged
off and came down
on the crown of mythe head
and he never allowed
an opportunity of the
kind to pass without
trying to inflict a kick
as if I neither had nor
deserved his love -

450
Robinson A remarkable peculiarity in the
forests of this country is the
absence of thorns - There
are but two exceptions
45 one a tree having a species
of the nux nux vomica
a small shrub very like
the plant of ^ the salsaparillasarsaparilla bearing
in addition to bun its
hooked thorns bunches
of yellow berries - The
thornlessness of the
vegetation is especially
noticeable to those who
have been in the South
where there is a so great
a variety of thorn bearing
plants and trees - We
have thorns of every size
and shape - thorns
straight thin & long - short
and thick hooked and
so strong as to be able
of to cut even leathern
like as a knife - Seed vessels
are scattered everywhere
by these appendages - One
lies flat as a shilling
with two thorns in
its centre ready to run
into the foot of any
animal that treads
upon it and stick there
for days together - Another ^
(the Uncaria procumbens) or grapple plant
451
has so many ^ hooked thorns as to
cling most tenaceouslytenaciously
to any animal to which
it may become attached
46 When it happens to attach
itself to the mouth of an
ox the animal stands
and roars with pain &
a sense of helplessness -

Whenever a part of
the forest has been cleared
for a garden ^ and abandnedabandoned a species
of Metonica plants
with leaves
like those
of ginger springs up
and contends for the
possession of the soil
with a great crop of
ferns - This is the
case all the way down
to Angola and shewsshows
the great difference of
climate between this and
the South Bechuana
country where a fern
except one or two
hardy species areis never
seen - - The metonica
plants above mentioned bear
a pretty pink flower
close to the ground
which is succeeded
by a scarlet fruit full
of seeds yielding as so
many fruits in this
country do a pleasant
acid juice which like
the rest is probably intended
452
as a corrective to the fluids
of the system in this hot
climate

47 On leaving the Chihune
we crossed the Longe and
it being a cloudy day we
our guides wandered in a forest away to the
west till we came to the
river Chihom-bo flowing
to the E- N- E-East North East My men
depend so much on
the sun for guidance
their having seen nothing
of the luminary all
day they thought we
had wandered back
to the Chiboque and as
often happens in these
cases they disputed
as to the point where
where the sun should
rise next morning
As soon as the rains
would allow we went
off to the East North East
It would have been
better to have travelled
by compass alone for
the guides took advantage
of any fears expressed
by my people and
threatened to return if
presents were not made
at once - But my men
453
had never left their own
country before except for
rapine and murder
When they came to a village
48 they were in the habit
of killing numbers of
the inhabitants and
then taking a few young
men to serve as guides
to the next place and As
this was their first attempt
and at ^ in an opposite line
of conduct - and being
without their shields they
felt defenceless among
the greedy Chiboque
and some allowance
must be made for
them on that account

SatSaturday 11th, Reached a small
village on the banks of
a little stream and I was
too ill to go out of my
little covering except
to quell a mutiny which
began to shewshow itself among
some of the Batoka and
Ambonda of our party
They grumbled as they
often do against their
chiefs when they
think them partial in
their gifts - because they
thought I had shewnshown
partiality to some of them in the
distribution of the beadss
